qas.question: Who ran the phones in Greece between 1949 and the 1980s?
What was the Hellenic Telecommunications Organization better known by the acronym of?
When did the liberalization of the telephone communications in Greece happen?
What company has a 40% stake in OTE?
How many shares of OTE does the Greek state own?
Who removed the phones in Greece between 1949 and the 1980s?
What was the Hellenic Telecommunications Organization not known as well by the acronym of?
When did the liberalization of the telephone communications in Greece become impossible?
What company lost a 40% stake in OTE?
How many shares of OTE does the Greek state sell?

context: Between 1949 and the 1980s, telephone communications in Greece were a <a0_0><b5_0>state<b5_0/><a0_0/> monopoly by the Hellenic Telecommunications Organization, better known by its acronym, <a1_0>OTE<a1_0/>. Despite the liberalization of telephone communications in the country in the <a2_0><b7_0>1980s<b7_0/><a2_0/>, <b6_0>OTE<b6_0/> still dominates the Greek market in its field and has emerged as one of the largest telecommunications companies in Southeast Europe. Since 2011, the company's major shareholder is <a3_0><b8_0>Deutsche Telekom<b8_0/><a3_0/> with a 40% stake, while the Greek state continues to own <a4_0><b9_0>10%<b9_0/><a4_0/> of the company's shares. OTE owns several subsidiaries across the Balkans, including Cosmote, Greece's top mobile telecommunications provider, Cosmote Romania and Albanian Mobile Communications.
